column2: Scan + Pay // Store of the Future: Scan and pay is an app that our Just4u customers use to scan items as they shop, pay and skip the checkout line in the mobile app. Pilot is live in 11 stores, 4 of which (Norcal) are live to customers.
column3: Scan and pay will give the ability to fully engage the customer, improve the customer experience, simplify their shopping journey, reduce contact in times of covid and pull this work into broader loyalty redesign strategy, bringing new features to our loyal members and give customers a new quick stop meal solution

column2: Location Services // Store of the Future: Piloting Product Search and Wayfinding. By understanding where the customer is in the store to serve information on items or products relevant to them in their shopping list on a moving map with pick path
column3: I love shopping for groceries large or small trips, but I hate that the items are located in different places, I don't know where to find a unique item or what it looks like and often leave with out it!
column8: Pilot Launch - Q1/Q2. UMA Launch Q3/Q4

column2: Freeosk // An in-store kiosk that offers customers free samples of products that are aimed at accelerating product and category discovery, influence new behaviors/purchases, and increase JFU signups.
column3: We know sampling drives incremental sales and we're looking for new opportunities to drive additional in-store revenue via CPG advertising. In addition with the start of the pandemic customers need a contactless sampling option.

User engagement
Incremental sales
Re-usage rates

column2: In-Store Mobile Congierge // Store of the Future: In-store scanning solution that will answer questions customers have while shopping; including how in season is the product, where it's sourced from, recipes, health information,  current promotions, and in store specialty ordering.
column3: I want a more intimate and personalized digital experience with my local store. Depending on experience I’m craving that day, I want to be able to find information or inspiration without having to talk to an associate or fumbling through multiple apps on my phone. I wish had a digital assistant to help me unlock the nuances of my store and its products.
column5:
User engagement
Incremental sales
Re-usage rates
Mobile app installs

column2: eCommunity // Albertsons' e-community is a platform welcoming all food lovers to seek inspiration, ask questions, join discussions, explore all things health, participate in events, share experiences, and create connections with those that share similar interests as well as with the Albertsons' family.
column3: Food and cooking can take on many roles in a person's life. It can bring joy, bring loved ones together, be a way to express your creativity, an escape, a challenge, a chore, or something intimidating. Whatever it may be, the journey begins in the store. That in-store experience is grounded in choice – how you choose to shop, whether it be about speed, or you enjoy browsing each aisle. It can be a social experience bonding with those behind the counters or a more introverted journey. On the other end, online is grounded in convenience but ultimately lacks the personal element and is more challenging to discover or become inspired. Albertsons' e-community is an extension of both in store and online that improves your experience and journey of choice. The platform can take on many forms: a way to generate your own content, browse others for inspiration, and create lasting connections.

column2: Bloom Cart by Safeway // Offer a unique/premium/on trend collection of hand-tied floral arrangements that can be delivered within 2 hours. The collection is aimed at customers who don't view ABS as a floral solutionin and result in new customer acquisition
column3: I love having fresh flowers in my home but find myself strapped for time to make this a priority. I wish there was a stylish and reliable solution.

column2: Food Trucks // Bring local & regional meal expansion via food trucks to our customers thoughout various business models inluding: food truck  events in our store parking lots, and connecting DuG and Delivery customers to food trucks near them.
column3: “I love to order from FOOD LOT while placing my grocery order on Albertsons App,” says Albertsons customer Christie Fullbelly.  “I schedule my pick-up time just prior to dinner so that I have a hot, ready to eat meal delivered to my car with my groceries, ready to be brought home to my family of hungry eaters! Each week we look forward to trying something new and exciting from FOOD LOT as well as ordering from our new favorites.  Some weekends, I’ll order dinner from FOOD LOT and wine from the grocery store, a full meal!”
column5: AOV, Engagement, Incremental Customers, Repeat Customers

column2: Healthy Shopping Assistant // Healthy shopping assistant pilot will	validate that ACI shoppers want to setup health/dietary/ingredient avoidance user profile and leverage those TAGs in their shopping experience online. Specifically on product detail pages and search.
column3: I am a busy, health focused customer looking for ways to shop for foods that help to manage or improve X condition in my life, but I don't want to spend additional time researching foods and my conditions. Please help make healthy shopping easy!

column2:
Project Menu // New & Improved Digital Features on UMA and web:

Recipe Search - Browse recipes & meals using search and filter tools (calories per serving, $ cost per serving, total cook time)
column3:
Understanding life is not predictable, Albertsons Digital Meal Solutions mission aims to remove the stress of meal planning for the week by providing our shoppers the tools needed to find last-minute meal solutions (recipes & prepared meals), easily create and organize weekly meal plans, create shopping lists and discover new recipes that inspire them and fit their dietary lifestyles and tastes. Our goal is to become everything food for our customers. 

Cooking 4-5 nights per week, our customers are looking for a variety of tasty, healthy, and budget-friendly meals and recipes to add to their rotation of family favorites.  But it needs to be easy, and customers prefer not to go to the grocery store more than once or twice a week.  They are tired of cooking the same meals each week and are looking to be inspired with new, easy-to-cook recipes to add to their weekly plan. Some nights they do not want to cook at all and are looking for quick, delicious, ready-to-heat and ready-to-eat options. 

We will remove the stress of meal planning for the week by providing our shoppers the tools needed to find last-minute meal solutions (recipes & prepared meals), easily create and organize weekly meal plans, create shopping lists and discover new recipes that inspire them and fit their dietary lifestyles and taste preferences.
column5: Engagement, AOV, Increase in Cart Size, Repeat Customers

column2: 3PL Tax/Payment API // This service will be initially piloted with Uber to enable automated tax exemption at the register, and give them an option to pay using a QR code. This solution will be rolled out nationally with Uber and Doordash.
column3: When Doordash, Uber and Instacart shoppers reach the register, there is a manual step process required to mark the transaction as tax exempt. Since this is a manual process, it is often overlooked or pushed back on by the cashier. In addition we are charged credit card processing fees for all the transactions that they ring up. We need an easy scanable solution to providing automated tax exemption for the transaction & a quick payment method with zero processing fees.
column5: Reduced tax reconciliation, Reduced transaction fees for CC

column2: Digital Screens // Use digital screens across the store to be able to: reduce the cost of print media, drive additional product sales through increased awareness of promotions and inspirational meal ideas.
column3: TBD - still working on strategy / how we will use (ie Décor, Advertising, etc)
column5: Incremental Sales, NPS, CSAT

Wine Club // Quickly launch Wine Club on Shopify platform, featuring Safeway Store 1257's (Livermore) large catalog assortment.  This will be a test & learn project with the goal to add inventory from other stores throughout the state.  
Build concept around the personal touch and personalities of our beverage stewards. Beverage stewards will help curate collections and mixed cases, choose and promote their favorites, and offer recommendations via live-chat on the site. 
Create SOPs for catalog management, merchandising, and fulfillment.
column3: I love my local Safeway’s wine team. Whenever I need a recommendation on a wine or beer to pair with a new recipe or restaurant take-out, or even just an introduction to something new, my local Safeway beverage team has me covered.  At times I feel I’ve exhausted the inventory featured at my local store and wish I had access to more variety to discover.
column5: Engagement, Repeat Customers

column2: Catalog Reporting: UI Dashboard / Power BI / Validation / Status // Digital Bundles - Provide customers with an enhanced shopping experience by seeing similar items clubbed together. Items may have different price points, and different images, but seeing those items clubbed together will allow customers to make purchases together at the time of order entry. Key metric is customer engagement time is made more productive with greater conversions.
column3: This will give user the ability to view/report on backend data that needs user attention example - SMIC that dont have a shelf code, number of blocks, CBA reporting etc
column5: Improved operational efficiency - User will not have to go through 20+ reports each week and this acts like a central place

column2: Digital Bundles // Provide the ability to add several attributes to Item Catalog to comply with federal, state, and local regulations on when and which items may be sold with regards to geography and timing.
column3: Customers today may not realize that while shopping for one item, they are forgetting to buy a related item. When our order workflow prompts the customer to consider items that go together, customers will appreciate the convenience of buying together. Potential basket size economies and discounting could be employed to make this initiative a win-win situation.
column5: Increased customer satisfaction, increased conversions due to reduced time searching for items leading to greater conversions.

column2: Item Restrictions // Provide the ability to group items that have a defined attribute with similar characteristics that make an item a variant. The concept of variant will group items with different flavors under one umbrella SKU. This prevents the customer from having to refer back and forth between different product pages since swatch images will show the variations of a product in one place.
column3: Customers get frustrated today seeing an item they would like to purchase only to find out during checkout that we prevent them from completing that transaction due to local laws (e.g. it is prohibited to sell alcohol in Texas on Sunday before noon).
column5: Indemnification against lawsuits for non-compliance against laws, reduced risk to lose liquor license; increased customer satisfaction since they are informed upfront what may or may not be added to cart

column2: SKU Relationships (e.g. Variants) // Develop technology to review expiry dates on items to take it out of stock when they are no longer eligible to be sold
column3: Customers find it time consuming to shop for different types of items that are very closely related (e.g. different flavors of icecreams) since these items are all displayed in different pages.
column5: Average basket size increase. Increased customer engagement with reduced time to build carts

column2: Perishable Items // Replicate Portland DS algorithms for instore items to apply logic so that OOS metrics are improved thereby providing a better shopping experience for our customers.
column5: Risk of selling expired items reduced, increased customer satisfaction, more accurate availability leading to better forecasting and decreased OOS.

column2: Replicate Portland test // Since FaR systems cannot provide inventory levels when they are running low, it is necessary to develop DS algorithms to predict low inventory levels at the item-store levels. These algorithms will take into account item inventory, forecast, picking, consumption, fulfillment to outline low inventory levels that will then be displayed to the customer. Iterating upon this logic will also provide customers the ability to reserve items in the future with a greater degree of accuracy.
column5: Decreased OOS

column5: Decreased OOS, increased availabilty, increased customer satisfaction

column2: Aisle L2 Redesign // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
Users are not able to find products easily, spending too much time navigating through the aisle and clicking too many times to find the product they are looking for. 
We don't showcase products by different categories to make it easy & fast for users to find the product. 
Products are not categorized by the way users shop, i.e users shop for coffee by type such as ground coffee, whole bean coffee, bottled coffee, etc.. vs users shop for soda by brand such as coca cola, pepsi, sprite, etc..
We don't incorporate deals into shoppable carousels to make it easy for users to find products on deals. 
We don't personalize the products on the aisles based on user's past purchase or past shopping behaviors. 
On L3 page, users are forced to do too much scrolling because products are not integrated into shoppable carousels. 
L1 page is not a shoppable page and it serves as an extra step for users to get to L2 page
We don't have category pages, instead we are using categories as filters which is not optimal for our SEO and user experience

Business Problem Statement:
Merchandising team does not have the ability to promote products according to the way customers shop such as type, brand, etc. All L2's follow the same page template and the format of the components cannot be edited.
column5: Traffic (+4%), Increase Units (+1.5), AOS (+$5.02), Conversion (+4 bps)  = +$17.8M

column2: Search & Aisle - Left Hand Nav (Filters) // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
Customer is unable to drill down into aisles or search results, making it difficult for them to find what they are looking for.  

Business Problem Statement:
Attribution will not only help customers filter down their items, but also provides more backend data to assist our search results to become more accurate.  Left Hand Nav is universal across all product categories and not unique to the item
column5: Conversion (+1.5% or 6bps) = $11M.  (Assuming search captures 60% of traffic)

column2: Search & Aisle - Visual Shelf Navigators // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
Currently, we don't have visual cues to help customers narrow down their browse/search results. Visual navigation based on customer decision tree data would help make the shopping experience easier for customers to find exactly what they want.

Business Problem Statement:
Visual navigation gives the merchandising team the capability to display our full customer offering in an easy, visual manner, including attributes, merch events, and deals

column2: PDP - Zoom Functionality // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
By adding zoom functionality to images, customers are able to see a more detailed view of the product and this will help drive their decision to add the item to cart. This will also bring us to parity with our competitors

Business Problem Statement:
PDPs are second biggest entry pages (13.5%) on the site but conversion rate is very low 0.5%
Today, we show only one product image that is static in size and does not provide customers additional clarity on the product

column2: PDP - Enhanced Content // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
By showing rich/enhanced content below the fold, customers can get a more well-rounded view of the product, and this will help drive their decision to add the item to cart. This will also bring us to parity with our competitors

Business Problem Statement:
PDPs are second biggest entry pages (13.5%) on the site but conversion rate is very low 0.5%
Today, we show only one product image that does not provide customers any additional detail than a product card. This is also an opportunity for the Shopper Marketing team to generate additional CPG revenue
column5: Conversion (+1% or 4 bps) = $3.4M

column2: PDP - Recipes // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
By adding a recipe carousel to the PDP, this inspires customers inspiration for various recipe ideas. Shopping on the PDP is not just transactional, but incorporates additional content for that ingredient

Business Problem Statement:
PDPs are second biggest entry pages (13.5%) on the site but conversion rate is very low 0.5%
This will give more visibility into the recipes experience, an opportunity to cross-sell and up-sell, and be a point of differentiation from competition
column5: Increase Units (+1), AOS (+$3.52), Conversion (+1% or 4 bps)  = +$15.6M (impacts Fresh Categories)

column2: PDP - Type 3 Pricing // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
Customer currently is only able to shop items in full lb quantities and not able to customize how much they can get

Business Problem Statement:
By allowing customization, ATC rates will increase as well as basket size (AOV); additional options for the customers to market fresh categories
column5: Increase Units (+1), AOS (+$3.52), Conversion (+1% or 4 bps)  = +$15.6M (impacts Fresh Categories)

column2: PDP - Cross Sell/Up Sell Carousels // nan
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
Customer gets visibility into more affinity items that are relevant to the current item they are viewing. Customer is unable to find items they are looking for because they can only live under one aisle (ex: Frozen breakfast items live under the breakfast aisle but customer is searching in the frozen aisle). 

Business Problem Statement:
Exposes customers to additional items outside of immediate product type and increases basket size (AOV) and ATC rate. Merchandising team is unable to surface relevant products to the customer in multiple aisles across the site because items are limited to one aisle only.
column5: Increase Units (+2), AOS (+$6.83 or +6.8%) = +$23.3M

column2:
SLOC as replacement for erums Store Setup (EOT) Tool and erums Store Services  // Preview environment to view unpublished version of website and mobile app content Phase 1:

- www-preview.banner.com (all banners including Mini Sites)
- Ability to preview fully functional banners sites
- Session Variable Framework support

Support following workflows (workflow version-1):  
-  Preview & Production Server
- Publish to Preview
- Publish to Preview & Production
- Deactivate/Unpublish from Preview & Production Workflow
column3:
Background:
SLOC is a pass-thru API service combining data inpuuted in Store Locator provider (YEXT) and  ERUM's ecommerce store setup too.  SLOC powers website, mobile app, and other systems that rely on store level data.  does not have a User-Interface to add/remove store level attributes. 

Problem Statement:
There has been a request to expire the Erums ecom store setup tool and associated API and move all functions to SLOC. In order to support this request, this requires SLOC to develop a User Interface to manage data (add, delete, change) as well as to clean-up data to fit SLOC model.

column2: Unified Search Engine // Brand Index first built with our faceted search links, but eventually will equate to LP's. Branded search volume for SEO is high and this would take advantage of that search volume. As well it will benefit paid search with better landing pages and ad sales in that they can offer ad rails for these brands and CPG's.
column3: Current user shopping experience on our site and app is not personalized. This initiative is to improve user experience by integrating user's past purchase data across the site as well as optimizing past purchases dedicated page
column5: Search PLP - CTR lift +10% || Search Conversion : +5% || Relevancey Measure (NDCG) + 10 points

column2: SEO - Brand Index // The faceted search pages are an underutilized set of page assets which SEO is trying get better indexed in Google. Due to the number of pages this encompases, being able to generate automated sitemaps to help indexation would ensure Google has picked up these pages.
column3: Business Problem Statement - There is a lot of search volume the business is not capturing well with aisle pages or PDPs. A brand index linked from the navigation would create stronger brand search presence in Google which equates to high volume traffic we are not well indexed for.
column5: - Increase search impressions on search pages by 30%. - Increase SEO visits on search pages by 12%

column2:
Faceted Links Sitemap // Identify SEO features that may not have sufficient quality coverage as part of todays test suites.
Introduce additional manual and automated tests to cover these scenarios.
Research on third party tooling to cover specialized SEO scenarios.
Introduce monitoring capabilities or cadence to review SEO metrics exposed on Google Search Console and other such dashboards. https://confluence.safeway.com/display/SCX/SEO+Automated+Testing
column3: Business Problem Statement - Faceted search pages have just become crawlable as an SEO asset, having autmated sitemaps for these pages will ensure indexing, visits, and stronger search placement in search engines.
column5: - Increase impressions on faceted search pages by 15% - Increase visits to faceted search pages by 10%

column2: SEO Automated Tests // The sitewide header is a great source to drive SEO traffic towards Category and Seasonal pages. Today the header links are generated client side and thus do not drive mmuch SEO value. Changes are required so that headers and links on the header are drawn serverside to increase link visibility to SEO bots. Also multiple level of Aisle page links need to be hosted on the header, potentially through the use of flyouts.
column3:
We have several SEO capabilities that are built into our E-Commerce banner sites. These capabilities have a large business value as they allow Search Engines to crawl our sites, add site links into their Search Engine indexes and serve the links as part of Search Engine Result Pages (SERP). SEO site features thus become invaluable in terms of driving customers to our E-Commerce sites. 

Given the business importance of the SEO features on the site it is paramount that we enhance testing practices and automation to regularly test and monitor these features.
column5: - Prevent losses, penalties, and catch issues before they cost us traffic due to search engines downscoring us. - As well, this should result in a 7% increase in total impressions and 3% increase in total traffic as a low end estimate. Note - This speaks to TOTAL impressions and traffic vs a specific page set.

column2: All Site Pages - Server side header and Header Updates // H1 header tags are currently controlled by AEM and require constant manual updates. - H1 tags that match the title and description metadata ensure stronger rankings for every page. - Lowering the pixel size to 1x1 ensures every page will have these without intruding on design and user experience. - Reduce user error. - Reduce manual labor.
column3: Business Problem Statement - The sitewide header today is drawn on the client side thus not driving much SEO value. Changes need to be made so the header links are included serverside to increase their SEO value
column5: Impressions were 11% and visits were projected at 6% (TOTAL) and not just specific page sets.

column2:
All Site Pages - Metatag Updates - H tags, title, description // Although it’s not the most critical ranking factor, having correctly optimized product URLs is recommended for several reasons.

It’s easier for search engines to understand
It’s easier for users to understand
It’s useful for readability purposes, especially in cases when you (or someone else) posts a URL of your products in a forum or a comment.
For example:

It’s easier to understand that this URL:

https://www.safeway.com/shop/red-bull-energy-drink-12-84-fl-oz/product-details.108100166.html

will lead to a product page about a Red Bull Energy drink than this:

https://www.safeway.com/shop/product-details.108100166.html     https://confluence.safeway.com/display/SCX/SEO+Contextual+PDP+URL+Assembly
column3: Business Problem Statement - AEM currently is where h1 tags are placed on pages. Currently, this is manual. As well, some h1 tags break design elements on pages. Not having h1 tags or having them listed as "hidden" as we currently do downscore and even draw cloaking penalties from Google.
column5: Prevent penalization of our pages where the current hidden tag is a Google violation. - Ensure targeted H1 tags which will improve SEO ranking on every page.

column2: PDP Pages - Contextual PDP URL assembly // The majority of retail sites have html sitemaps. This is usually a page liked to in the sitewide footer that leads to a page that has hyperlinks of important pages such as Aisles. This mainly plugs SEO strength from the number of anchored links across the footer to the main pages such as aisle and the brand index we are building.
column3:
Product Detail pages have the highest counts among on all pages on our site. As such they hold a log of value from an SEO organic traffic driving potential. Our PDP page URL today follows the below format where the purpose / identity of the page is not very clear from the URL.

PDP URL Format: https://www.safeway.com/shop/product-details.<BPN>.html
column5: - Having url assembly that better matches the actual product will increase PDP impressions by 10-12% - This should also increase SEO clicks by 3%-7%

column2: Sitewide Footer Link /HTML Sitemaps // The recipe pages offer a huge boon for SEO traffic as they are not SEO optimized need schema markups that dentote to Google that this is a recipe. Schema markups will help search when people are searching for recipes. In other words, the markup greatly increases the chance Google will index these pages higher. As well, FAQ on these pages and all LP's are another large SEO opportunity as Google favors question based search and pages that have FAQ on them.
column3: We do not have an html sitemap and therefore are not casting SEO voting power or placing importance on main category / aisle pages. As well, this makes it harder for us to force bots into the site to crawl pages such as pharmacy. This is especially important because our existing navigation is Javascript and does not cast SEO voting strength into any of our category pages.
column5: - Having real html links to our main pages will lift our impressions by 8% and our clicks by 4%.

column2: FAQ and Recipe Schema markups // Our aisle page taxonomy id issues have caused products to appear on aisle URLS that do not fit them properly. This is creating urls that don't match the products on the pages at all.
column3: The existing recipe pages have no SEO optimization or schema markups or FAQ. This greatly reduces their chances of ranking in Google or social media searches.
column5: - Having schema markp and faq on these pages should raise impressions on the recipe pages by 2000% and should increase clicks by no less than 200% on recipe pages.

column2: Search & Aisle Taxonomy updates // All suggestions made WoW by Merkle are chronicled here and are the items they feel are most heavily impacting SEO. As well, these items represent issues that need to be corrected or potential wins.
column3:
Customer Problem Statement:
Browse customers are unable to find the products they are looking for within the current taxonomy hierarchy (aisles and shelves). 

Business Problem Statement:
Merchandising team is unable to strategically update aisles based on assortment, category expertise and CDT; Updating taxonomy also helps increase SEO value.
column5: - This is more about not losing credibility in Google with these types of poorly fitting links. - Correcting this would prevent us from losing 3% of our traffic on Aisle pages and would likely result in us gaining another 3%.

column2: Merkle Vendor Reccomendations // Data from various sources (Syndigo, vestcome, Label Insights etc) will be collected and stored in a central repository (EDM)
column3: https://jira.safeway.com/browse/SXP-2456
column5: Merkle's suggestions should lift our overall impressions by 18% and overall traffic by 10%

column2: Instore -Digital parity with health claims(Gluten free, organic) and other attributes // TBD
column3: This feature will help create parity between Instore and Online health claims
column5: Parity between Instore- Online health claims attributes

column2: HSA/FSA // nan
column3:
FSA- and HSA-eligible products such as contact lenses, first aid supplies and sun care can be paid for in store or online with your FSA or HSA card.

With the passing of the 2020 CARES Act, many new items and categories are now eligible without a prescription, including cough and cold, allergy and sinus and more. Contact your FSA administrator for more information.
